response.answer_text: No — in fact, I’ve been roundly called too pragmatic. I do have my ideals — but I’m not an idealist, and I’ve never been seen by anyone as “idealistic.” I know lots of stuff about the ideal ways to doing things or ways of living — because my generation of people (the 50-somethings and older) mostly happen to know them too. Yet I’m a out-and-out pragmatist. You know you have a diehard pragmatist in your midst when:— You ask a hypothetical question and almost upfront and early you get told (and told off in a diplomatic way) to restructure your question in a more realistic way, such as:—How do you use three pigs to test for poison in one bucket out of 100 buckets of water/feed? — The idealist spins up into working out various mathematical and probabilistic solutions. The pragmatist tells you to stop using expensive ASSETS like livestock to test for poison and use a poison-testing kit, which is standard equipment on farms anyway. That’s one helluva way of telling you off, isn’t it?A query about language usage is met with a usage answer and followed up with a grammar explanation — instead of grammar first with idealists.Any pragmatist is driven mostly by inductive reasoning rather than deductive reasoning — the difference between Sam Spade and Philip Marlowe (inductive) vs. Sherlock Holmes (deductive).A pragmatist is unlikely to quibble about particular points and take things at face value (“as-is”) until something better comes along. Something is presumed to be the ‘truth’ until it isn’t.I can hold my own in intellectual discussions, but I’m not an intellectual and no one regards me as one — in case anyone is wondering about that too.

Are you too idealistic? Not on the outside. Most people wouldn’t have a clue what goes on in my head and they’d probably not understand most of it. lol :) I’m not sure why “idealistic” has negativity attached to it. Having ideas and dreams about a better world doesn’t mean a person is disregarding reality. The reason I’m idealistic within my thoughts is because I’ve accepted that reality is a harsh and violent existence. And I’d truly prefer that the planet I lived on was a safer and healthier environment for everyone. It isn’t. I love being idealistic. It is one of my favorite states of being.
